Establish processes to control the unique identities of users and services. The process for managing user IDs should include using unique user IDs to enable users to be linked to and held responsible for their actions; the use of shared IDs should only be permitted where they are necessary for business or operational reasons and should be approved and documented.

Enforce the use of individual user IDs and strong passwords to maintain accountability.

Below is an example of different password parameters to achieve strong quality passwords:

  • Minimum password length: 8 characters or more characters (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Password complexity: Enabled
  • Password History - 24 Passwords (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Maximum Password Age - 90 days (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Lockout attempts: 5-10 attempts (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Multi-factor Authentication

For Serverless Functions (if applicable):

The authentication resources provided by the serverless environment can also be used. For example, AWS Cognito or Single Sign-On AWS API Gateway authorization facilities (link) Azure App Service Authentication / Authorization Google Firebase Authentication IBM BlueMix AppID or SSO.

MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication) adds extra security because it requires users to provide unique authentication in addition to their regular sign-in credentials. There are various methods to setup authentication for serverless functions, such as:

  • OAuth Authentication - Running your application serverless with the latest and more secure mode of authentication
  • API Key Authentication - The simplest and the fastest way to enable authentication.

Enforce documented password parameters for access to applications through automated configurations such as minimum password length, complexity, password history, maximum age, account lockout interval, and threshold.
The use of unique accounts must be enforced i.e. dedicated account for each user. Use of generic accounts (if needed for business purpose), must be logged and monitored.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is an effective way to provide enhanced security that verifies a user's identity by requiring multiple credentials. If a system/service has a multi-factor authentication (MFA) functionality, turn it on.

Examples of Multi-Factor Authentication include using a combination of these elements to authenticate:

    • Codes generated by smartphone apps
    • Badges, USB devices, or other physical devices
    • Soft tokens, certificates
    • Fingerprints
    • Codes sent to an email address
    • Facial recognition
    • Retina or iris scanning
    • Behavioural analysis
    • Answers to personal security questions

In addition to a password, consider multi-factor authentication for enhanced security with these factors
- Things you know (knowledge), such as a password or PIN
- Things you have (possession), such as a badge or smartphone
- Things you are (inheritance), indicated through biometrics, like fingerprints or voice recognition

It is essential that all critical applications should have Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) allowed.

A standardized procedure for granting and revoking access should be established. Access to systems and supporting infrastructure should be granted to users based on the standardized process and after approval from designated personnel on the principle of least privilege required to perform job functions. Documented approval in the form of email, ticket, or checklist should be retained as audit evidence. 

Basic: Create and maintain a spreadsheet that tracks all employees and which corporate accounts/systems and supporting infrastructure that they have been provided access to and who authorized their specified access. Track when they have been given access and when access has been removed depending upon whether their roles have changed or if they have left the organization. Please ensure the access to spreadsheets is restricted to authorized personnel only and tracks version control.

Advanced: Implement an HR and People Management onboarding system that is integrated with your Identity & Access Management (IAM) system. Activate and Suspend (do not delete) user accounts to preserve audit trails.

For Serverless Functions (If applicable):

The organization should have a procedure to provide access to accounts that call out services and enforce authentication with the use of serverless authentication methods. There are various methods to setup authentication for serverless functions, such as:

  • OAuth Authentication - Running your application serverless with the latest and more secure mode of authentication
  • API Key Authentication - The simplest and the fastest way to enable authentication.

Access to serverless functions should be on the principle of least privilege, meaning you can only access exactly what you need the following authorization. In addition, most serverless functions have different needs; creating a single role for all the functions in the application can open up security holes. The risk can be mitigated by creating a different role for every function and restricting each function to its intended purpose.

Establish and follow a termination checklist to ensure that the termination process is consistently executed and access is revoked for terminated employees in a timely manner. For the list, consider:

  • The type of access to be revoked (ex. Physical access to the building or administrator access to a software tool).
  • Physical assets that need to be returned (ex. ID cards or laptops).
  • Network and system access - ensure access is terminated on the same day. Also, to any applications or system components that the terminated user had access to.
  • Passwords for shared accounts - ensure passwords to such accounts are either changed or disabled (as required). This also includes email and remote access.

Upon notification, system administrators will disable/delete the employees' user accounts in applicable systems, including supporting systems and sensitive utilities (application, database, and support services servers; databases; cloud storage).

Basic: Use an onboarding/offboarding document and process where HR personnel informs system administrators or asset owners for timely revocation of access.
Advanced: Implement a central access control system to manage access depending on their employment status and job changes.

  • Create a dedicated account for personnel requiring privileged access commensurate with their job responsibilities.
  • These accounts should not be used for browsing the web, checking email, and doing day-to-day tasks.
  • Activities performed using these accounts should be logged and monitored. The organization should try to minimize the use of generic administrator accounts. In the event that it is not possible, only very few people should have access to it, and the access should be provided on a need-to-have basis.

In order to assess whether the accounts (user and non-users) with administrative access are restricted to authorized personnel, management can rely on the evidence of access reviews performed for such accounts. Additionally, evidence of the user's job titles/designations can be provided to inspect the appropriateness.

In order to detect any unauthorized access to organizational systems, a periodic review (preferably quarterly) of user access rights along with roles associated with it needs to be performed. The reviews must be performed by designated management personnel or asset owner and are required to be documented for audit purposes. Things to consider while performing access reviews:
- Perform review on all accounts (user as well as non-user accounts) and roles associated with it
- Users with access should not perform a review of their own accounts. For exceptions, a secondary review needs to be performed by other management personnel
- Document the review and corrective actions resulting from it. Corrective actions must be implemented at the earliest following review.
- Review, as well as the implementation of corrective actions, needs to be performed in a timely manner.

Based on review if there is an identified need for an access change or corrective action, then this must be documented and reported for change to be modified as appropriate. Documentation of reviews includes - tickets, emails, listings used to perform the review, results of review captured through emails or tickets, etc.

Customer data are logically separated by an organization ID (org_id) column in the DB and enforced using logic rules. It can also be segregated by maintaining separate S3 buckets per customer and a shared database by regions (store US data separate from EU).

Organizationally-owned or managed (physical and virtual) applications, and infrastructure system and network components, shall be designed, developed, deployed, and configured such that provider and customer (tenant) user access is appropriately segmented from other tenant users, based on the following considerations:
Established policies and procedures
Isolation of business critical assets and/or sensitive user data, and sessions that mandate stronger internal controls and high levels of assurance
Compliance with legal, statutory, and regulatory compliance obligations

Segregation of Duties (SOD) is a basic building block of sustainable risk management and internal controls for a business. The basic concept underlying segregation of duties is that no employee or group should be in a position both to perpetrate and to conceal errors or fraud in the normal course of their duties. Thus, SOD is accomplished by having different duties performed by different individuals, such as developers should not have access to implement or promote changes into production. Only designated individuals from IT can promote changes to production following the organization's change management process.

If the organization is unable to implement SOD control as recommended due to the size of the team or any other restrictions, they should consider compensating controls and/or detective controls to mitigate the risk posed by excessive access (inappropriate SOD). Some examples of additional controls that can be considered include but not limited to:

  • Provide temporary access to production (emergency access or also known as firefighter access). Such access can be provided for an approved window of time and later revoked. Since the access is provided to a handful of people, it makes it easier to review the activity logs.
  • Organizations can perform code reviews or review change logs in production. 
  • Alert notification can be configured on the production server to send notification emails or alerts whenever a change is directly migrated to the production server. Alerts should be assigned and reviewed by the authorized personnel.

  • Review, customize and publish the pre-populated policies in your infosec program to align them with your organization processes.
  • Ensure that policies are reviewed and approved by management at least annually and accessible to all the employees of the organization through the Policy module via the "InfoSec Program" menu on the left navigation bar of the platform.
  • The policy should include the organization's mission and objectives.

    • An information security awareness programme should aim to make employees and, where relevant, contractors aware of their responsibilities for information security and how they are discharged. The information security awareness programme should be established in accordance with the organization's information security policies and procedures, taking into account the organization's information to be protected and the controls that have been put in place to protect the information. It is important to concentrate not only on the 'what' and 'how' but also on the 'why' when writing an awareness document as this helps employees understand the purpose of information security and the potential impact.
    • Awareness training should be performed as required by the organization’s information security awareness programme. Awareness training can use different delivery media, including classroom-based, distance learning, web-based, self-paced and others. Organizations must establish formal information security awareness training for the employees. All employees must go through the training as part of the onboarding process and at least annually thereafter.
    • The Awareness Training report should contain content on security and privacy awareness training.

All designated customer administrators and relevant organizational employees must be made aware of the functional use of the application/services a company provides. This can be achieved through either of the below for new customer administrators as well as employees:
- Maintaining and sharing a user guide that specifies application functionality
- Having an onboarding session/meeting to guide on functional use of the application
- Having a 'Help' option in the application where users can refer to the guide

In addition, the roles and responsibilities of relevant stakeholders are required to be communicated through training or other documents as part of the onboarding process.

Refer to the template "SOC 2 - System Description Outline and A Sample of Section 3 - SOC 2 Report" to aid with evidence collection.

  • Change Management is the process to manage the introduction of any enhancement, modification, update, installation, or removal of any hardware, software, interface, or database, or document that will impact the existing production environment. It ensures that only approved modifications to the environment are implemented.
  • The change management process must include all the steps that start from a change identification and documentation, change review and prioritization, impact analysis, testing, change approval or rejection, implementation, and finally, a post-implementation review and change request closure.

It further defines the type of changes and how to deal with or process each category of changes.

  • Standard Change - A change that is part of the daily routine, is considered low risk, and has a predictable outcome may be pre-approved. Organizations can define a list of such pre-approved changes in the change management process.
  • Emergency Change - A change that is directly related to a critical priority incident and must be implemented to restore service is an Emergency change.
  • Normal change - A considerable change in a service or IT infrastructure and needs to be reviewed and approved by the change manager prior to its implementation.

Change Management Process needs to be established and consistently followed for each change. The process document needs to be reviewed by management at least annually or in case of significant updates.

Emergency change is a change that should be evaluated and implemented as soon as possible after the occurrence of a disaster or a damaging incident, and it is implemented as a solution. An Emergency change is required for two reasons:
1) due to a fault to restore a service to users (Break-Fix)
2) to prevent a foreseen major impact to a business-critical system or service.
An example would be, to resolve a major incident or implement a security patch to a zero-day exploit or network isolation from a DDOS attack.

The emergency change process must be established and followed when a change needs to be implemented in a compressed time frame due to the nature of the change. Emergency change requests need to be documented and subject to the standard change management process but at an accelerated timeline. Approvals are also required to be obtained for such changes in the form of discussing the matter with a relevant service manager. Such changes should be assessed and formally approved retrospectively.

Systems development life cycle phases include planning, system analysis, system design, development, implementation, integration and testing, and operations and maintenance. The following aspects should be put under consideration in a System Development Life Cycle:
- Security of the development environment
- Guidance on the security in the software development lifecycle
- Security in the software development methodology
- Secure coding guidelines (OWASP)
- Security requirements in the design phase;
- Security checkpoints within the project milestones
- Secure repositories
- Security in the version control
- Security knowledge, i.e. developers’ capability of avoiding, finding and fixing vulnerabilities.
Without formally implementing the SDLC and generating the requisite deliverables, it is challenging to effectively manage the development process and ensure that security-related issues are adequately addressed.

Ensure communication is a key step in your change management process. Accordingly, establish a formal channel to communicate changes that affect the functionality and security of the system components to relevant stakeholders which includes employees, affected customers and contractors prior to the change. Such notification must include who is affected by the change, time, duration, affected areas, expected result as well as any action item required from the users.

All changes must be handled in accordance to the defined change management process includes all the steps that start from a change identification, change request, request review, and prioritization by the change review board, evaluation through impact analysis, change approval or rejection, change testing, implementation, and finally a post-implementation review and request closing.

A ticketing system or a change management form/log can be used to track changes made to the production systems. All changes must be documented, tested and authorized. Documentation is important to track what changes are requested as well as implemented. Documentation must include at a minimum:
- Change description
- Impact or risk
- Change window
- Implementation and testing plan
- Backout plan etc ( it is a contingency plan in case the change fails in the production environment.)

For testing, it is required to evaluate if change meets the intended purpose. The change should be tested by the change developer/tester first, and then tested again by an end user or users. The testing results should be captured to demonstrate that the change meets acceptance criteria.

All proposed changes need to be approved by designated management personnel based on the change management process. The review and approval process differs in organizations. Some companies institute change through their control board, and it is the authorized body to review and approve all CRs. Some smaller companies may not have the change control board, but require IT and business approvals for change requests. Things to be considered while approving changes:
- Impact of change
- Results of testing etc
- Whether there are backups plans

Development involves a lot of debugging and testing; thus, any new change needs to be developed in a separate development environment and tested in a test environment before making changes to production. An example setup could have development, staging/testing and production environments:

Development: The development environment would be the first line of defence against bugs. In it, developers deploy their code and test any newly implemented features. Any bugs found must be dealt with before re-deploying for further testing. The process is iterated until the code is ready for the next stage of testing.

Staging/Testing: Once developers are satisfied with their code and consider it fairly stable, it is then deployed to the staging environment for further testing. This is where Quality Assurance (QA) is performed. Testers access the staging servers and ensure that the application works as it should. They run test cases to detect bugs and run performance tests to find areas that could be improved. Any bugs or enhancements are reported back to the developers, and the process is repeated until the code passes the staging phase.

Production: Once the code has been thoroughly tested, it is then pushed to production, where it is made available to end-users.

The backup aims to create a copy of data that can be recovered in the event of a primary data failure. Backup copies allow data to be restored from an earlier point in time to help the business recover from an unplanned event. Thus, an organization must define the process and frequency of data backups in the back and recovery procedure along with its retention at an offsite location. Backups should be performed consistently with the defined schedule and criticality of data.

In addition, a process should be implemented to monitor backup failures. This can be achieved by configuring automated alerts that generate an email/notification to IT personnel in the event of an automated backup failure. Failed backups must be re-run to ensure completeness of data backup.

Create and maintain a secondary site in the event of a disaster and failure of the primary site. This includes the following:

A failover or secondary facility is available to recover systems in the event of an outage. If using a cloud computing provider (e.g. AWS), data centers must be in different geographic regions. Backup data is rotated to an offsite location to a geographically different area that Management determined necessary in the event of an environmental threat. Failover environments are readily available or arrangements made for alternative environments in the event the primary environment is not available for production processing.

- Maintain an alternate/secondary site to recover systems and services

- Backup data is replicated (e.g. S3 replication in a different AWS region)

- Cloud computing services (e.g. EC2 servers) are located in two separate geographic regions

Ensure alternate sites are available for immediate restoration in the event the primary site is down (e.g. AMI available to spin up automatically in a secondary cloud environment).

Documented recovery plans (such as Disaster Recovery) should be developed, maintained, reviewed and tested on a periodic basis.

Ensure that for disaster recovery, the following aspects are covered and documented in plans:

  • A management structure is in place to prepare for, mitigate and respond to a disruptive event.
  • Appoints an incident response personnel or team with the appropriate responsibility, authority and competence to manage the incident of systems.
  • Recovery procedures are developed and approved detailing how information business objectives will be met during disruptive events.
  • Compensating controls for information security controls that cannot be maintained during an adverse situation.
  • Test Disaster Recovery plans at regular intervals in order to ensure that they are valid and effective during adverse situations.

Refer to the template "Disaster Recovery Plan" to aid with evidence collection.

  • A privacy policy should state how a company or website collects, handles and processes data of its customers/ data subjects. It explicitly describes whether that information is kept confidential or is shared with or sold to third parties. Include specific language to regional privacy laws in your privacy statement.
  • Publish a public privacy policy statement on your organization's website and any online applications.
  • Publish an employee privacy policy statement on your organization's intranet and HR handbook.
  • Some of the basic elements that a privacy policy should include:
      • What data is being collected? How is that data being collected?
      • What is the legal basis for the collection? (e.g. consent, necessary for your service, legal obligation etc.
      • For which specific purposes are the data collected? Analytics? Email Marketing?
      • The categories of sources from which you collect personal information.
      • Which third parties will have access to the information? Will any third party collect data through widgets (e.g. social buttons) and integrations (e.g. Facebook connect)?
      • Where applicable, details relating to cross-border/ overseas data transfer and which measures were put into place to facilitate this in a safe and compliant way.
      • What rights do users have? Can they request to see the data you have on them? Can they request to rectify, erase or block their data?
      • Description of process for notifying users and visitors of changes or updates to the privacy policy
      • The effective date of the privacy policy

The disposal or decommissioning process is in place to identify the list of storage devices (physical and virtual) that are no longer required or have reached the end of their useful life.

For virtual storage drives, the organization is responsible for deleting data if the storage is no longer in use or needs to be reused.

Note: Cloud service providers, such as AWS, use a shared responsibility model for deleting data from virtual drives/storage. The organization first deletes the Elastic Block Store (EBS) volume or Simple Storage Service (S3) bucket, after which AWS removes any data and prepares the infrastructure for reuse. For EBS, the organization could securely wipe the EBS volume before deleting it.

Information security roles and responsibilities of employees, contractors, and the organization should be stated in contractual agreements. The organization should ensure that employees and contractors agree to terms and conditions concerning information security appropriate to the nature and extent of access they will have to the organization’s assets associated with information systems and services. Where appropriate, responsibilities contained within the terms and conditions of employment should continue for a defined period after the end of the employment

A code of conduct may be used to state the employee’s or contractor’s information security responsibilities regarding confidentiality, data protection, ethics, appropriate use of the organization’s equipment and facilities, as well as reputable practices expected by the organization.

Employees should be made aware of their roles and responsibilities regarding their job and information security through the job description and periodic training. Job responsibilities must be documented in job descriptions and made available to employees during onboarding and when significant changes occur. Management personnel should review and approve the job descriptions on at least an annual basis or any significant changes (whichever is earliest).

The organization chart aims to illustrate the reporting relationships and chains of command within the organization. The organization chart helps to demonstrate clear reporting structures for all the employees in the organization.

An Organizational chart must be developed to provide a quick understanding of how the organization is designed, its number of levels, and where each employee fits into the organization. The organization chart must be authorized by management, communicated to employees and reviewed/updated on a periodic basis or in case of significant changes.

  • One of the ways to evaluate the competency of employees is through performance evaluation. Performance evaluation is a formal and productive procedure to measure an employee's competence, performance and results based on their job responsibilities.
  • Organizations should formally define employee Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and evaluate those KPIs through performance evaluations at least annually.

Refer to the template "Performance Evaluation" to aid with evidence collection.

Management must encourage employees to complete and continue formal education and technical certification programs by developing a formal training plan that aligned with job functions. The training needs are required to be captured in the formal training plan and compliance to the plan needs to be evaluated either as part of annual performance evaluations or through other means and updated based on strategic need or changing industry trends.

In addition, the training plan should also capture the training needs with respect to information security awareness in accordance with the organization's information security policies and procedures, taking into account the organization's information to be protected and the controls that have been put in place to protect the information. Awareness training can use different delivery media including classroom-based, distance learning, web-based, self-paced and others.

Background verification and reference checks are required to be conducted on all candidates for employment proportional to the business requirements, the classification of the information to be accessed, and the perceived risks in accordance with relevant laws, regulations and ethics. Background verification should take into account all relevant privacy, protection of personally identifiable information and employment based legislation. In addition, to evaluate the competency of personnel- reference checks shall be performed.

The organization may consider more detailed verification of the potential employee where a job, involves the person having access to sensitive information. A background check is used to look up education credentials, criminal, commercial, or maybe financial records of a candidate. Whereas, a reference check looks to find the perfect employee fit, and protect the company from a poor performer or a bad hire.

Background and reference checks are normally performed for all employees whereas contractors normally are not part of this process as they are considered as "vendors" and evaluated as part of vendor assessments but the organization may decide to include contractors as part of this control based on the risk they may pose to the organization.

Incidents are unplanned events of any kind that disrupt or reduce the quality of service (or threaten to do so). The organization must establish an incident Management Process for managing the lifecycle of all incidents irrespective of their origination within agreed service level agreements (SLAs) and must be reviewed by management on at least an annual basis. An effective Incident Management Process should focus on restoring normal service operations as quickly as possible, minimizing the adverse impact on business operations as well as ensuring that agreed levels of service quality are maintained.

  • Ensure that standardized methods and procedures are established and used for an efficient and prompt response, analysis, documentation, ongoing management and reporting of Incidents
  • Increase visibility and communication of Incidents to business and IT support staff
  • Align Incident management activities and priorities with those of the business
  • Maintain user satisfaction with the quality of IT services

The organization must ensure that all information security incidents are responded to in line with the formal incident management process. The first goal of incident response is to resume ‘normal security level’ and then initiate the necessary recovery. Incident management should include the below at minimum:
- Collecting evidence as soon as possible after the occurrence
- Conducting security forensics analysis, as required
- Escalation, as required;
- Ensuring that all involved response activities are properly logged for later analysis
- Communication to internal and external people or organizations with a need-to-know
- Dealing with information security weakness(es) found to cause or contribute to the incident;
- Once the incident has been successfully dealt with, formally closing and recording it and performing post-incident analysis

Refer to the template "Incident Tracking and Notification Template" to aid with evidence collection.

Management must establish and document the roles and responsibilities to oversee the implementation of security policies, including incident response. For incident response, a dedicated incident response team must be assigned to oversee and prioritize actions during an incident, including detection, analysis, and containment of an incident, in addition to conveying the special requirements of high severity incidents to the rest of the company. The incident response team should be made up of the security lead, corporate IT and at least one executive.

Roles and Responsibilities can be documented in the "Information Security" policy or a separate document such as the incident response procedure.

An incident response procedure is a collection of procedures aimed at identifying, investigating and responding to potential security incidents (or disasters) in a way that minimizes impact and supports rapid recovery. Management is required to incorporate lessons learned from ongoing incident response activities into incident response procedures on an ongoing basis.

Lessons learned from incident response activities must be analyzed, and the incident response plan and recovery procedures should be improved accordingly. Once the investigation is complete, hold an after-action meeting with all Incident Response Team members and discuss what you've learned from the incident. Determine what worked well in your response plan and where there are gaps. Questions to address:

  • What changes need to be made to the security as well as incident response plan?
  • How should employees be trained differently?
  • What weakness did the incident exploit?
  • How will you ensure a similar incident doesn't happen again?

Identify system components (virtual instances and/or physical) associated with information and information processing facilities in your organization and maintain an inventory for such assets. The asset inventory should be accurate, up-to-date, and consistent.
 
Examples of asset types: Servers (virtual instances/physical), workstations, software/applications, Wireless Access Points, documents, etc.
The asset inventory should consist of but not limited to 
  • Asset Type
  • Asset Owner
  • Asset Classification
  • Asset location

Refer to the template "Asset_Inventory_Management" to aid with evidence collection.

The Board of Directors (BOD) should have sufficient members who are independent of management and objective in evaluations and decision making. In addition, the BOD must define, maintains, and periodically evaluates the skills and expertise needed among its members to enable them to ask probing questions to senior management and take commensurate action.

Organizations without BOD can change the control language with this compensating control:  Executive management meets on a quarterly basis for oversight of internal controls, operations and business objectives.

The Board of Directors or executive management ensures that the organization is meeting its business commitment as expected and must meet on a periodic basis (preferably on a quarterly basis) for oversight on internal controls, operations and business objectives.
Example of evidence to demonstrate the commitment of BOD on internal controls:
- Minutes of the meeting that show that the Board monitors and evaluates the implementation of policy strategies and business plans.
- Management committed to meet compliance and business requirement by investing in the OneTrust platform.

The Board of Directors' oversight responsibilities to achieve business commitments, including those required to achieve security and confidentiality commitments, need to be defined and documented. For example, in company mandate or charter. Any new member of the board needs to read and formally acknowledge the defined responsibilities. All existing board member is required to formally acknowledge these responsibilities on an annual basis thereafter. 

Refer to the template "Board of Directors Charter" to aid with evidence collection.

Organizations without BOD can change the control language with this compensating control:  Executive management oversight responsibilities are defined and documented and acknowledged by the Executive team on an annual basis.

  • A well-written code of conduct clarifies an organization's mission, values and principles, linking them with standards of professional conduct. In addition, the code of conduct and ethics encourages open communication with employees, managers, and subordinates relating to conflict resolution, along with directives on reporting any improper behaviour promptly through appropriate channels.
  • The code of conduct and ethics reiterates that employees who violate company policies or engage in other misconduct are subject to appropriate disciplinary action up to and including termination.
  • Organizations must establish a documented code of conduct and ethics.
  • The documents need to be approved and reviewed by management at least annually.
  • All employees must acknowledge the code of conduct during onboarding or any significant changes thereafter.

The organization can create separate policy documents for both corporate ethics and acceptable usage to meet the control requirement. A process should be implemented to enforce the acknowledgment of these documents by employees during the onboarding process or annually thereafter. Records of acknowledgment should be retained for audit purposes.


On a periodic basis (preferably), management should review these policies to verify their relevance and update them as required. The documents may cover topics like:
- Business ethics and the Code of Conduct
- Intellectual property and confidentiality
- Conflicts of interest
- Securities laws and disclosure
- Anti-corruption and international business
- Acceptable use of assets

Whistleblowing is where a worker reports wrongdoing, most frequently discovered at work, in order to protect the company. Whistleblowing complaints include, but are not limited to, criminal offenses, environmental damage and health and safety threats. Setup services like phone helplines, hotlines, text messaging, phone/fax, email or online chat facilities for employees that would allow anonymous reporting and allow designated personnel to verify these anonymous tips and escalate accordingly.

For smaller companies, google forms can be used as well to anonymously report issues related to fraud, harassment and other issues impacting the organization's ethical and integrity requirements.

Refer to the template "Anonymous Reporting Form " to aid with evidence collection.

Insurance is a way of managing risks, i.e. transferring the cost of a potential loss to the insurance company in exchange for a fee. Based on the results of security risk assessments, management must maintain commercial general liability insurance, which includes technology/professional errors and omissions coverage. In addition, cyber insurance is also an important consideration for small businesses. Cyber coverage can help to protect a company from the costs of data breach notification, remediation, payment penalties, crisis management etc.

A risk assessment is conducted annually to identify the risk factors and determine if the existing controls are adequate to manage the risk. This assessment should be done by a competent person or team of individuals who have a good working knowledge of the environment. In addition, it is important to ensure that identified risks and treatment strategies are documented and implemented.

Refer to the template "Risk Assessment and Treatment Template" to aid with evidence collection.

Cybersecurity insurance aims to assist organizations in contacting and supporting affected customers, employees, etc., after their personal information has been compromised. It also assists organizations in covering the costs of restoring systems and recovering data in the event of a cyber attack.

Cyber security insurance covers some of these cyber risks.

Personal information is lost due to electronic or physical theft of electronic data, physical theft of hard copy files, and procedural errors.

Hacking, viruses, and other malicious code and denial of service attacks can damage or destroy business operational data and software.

This coverage may also be helpful if an organization is named in a lawsuit or claim due to a data breach or cyber attack.

Anti-virus software should be installed and maintained on systems running services within the organization's network. Protection against malware should be based on malware detection and repair software, information security awareness and appropriate system access and change management controls.

Antivirus software must be installed on all production systems. Ideally, try to install such software on all other server and client systems that have to interact with the production systems. Configure installation of software updates and antivirus definition updates on a regular basis.

For an organization that does not have AV installed on its Linux servers because of the high-level security in its operating system.
We recommend that these servers are updated - all patches and security updates are installed, run a firewall on the system to block unused ports and subscribe to the Red hat subscription management. The objective is to ensure these servers are protected and access to them is managed.
ClamAV is an AV that works on Linux but is not distributed or supported by Red Hat.

Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to information systems.

Baseline configuration is a snapshot of the configuration at a specific time. For example, if you retrieved the configuration for a server or router that information is a snapshot of how the device was configured at the time when it was retrieved. Baseline configuration management involves periodically retrieving the configuration of the asset and comparing it to the baseline. If no changes have occurred, no action is required. If one or more changes have occurred, the change(s) must be assessed, verified, and documented or rolled-back to the baseline configuration. Baseline configurations include (but not limited to) information about information system components such as:

• Functional settings that determine how the asset operates 
• Versions of software currently installed (includes BIOS, firmware, operating system, applications, etc.) 
• Patches (including security patches) that are installed 
• Ports that are active for normal and emergency operations and how they are configured 
• Services that are enabled.

Automated mechanisms that help organizations maintain consistent baseline configurations for information systems include, for example, hardware and software inventory tools, configuration management tools, and network management tools. Such tools can be deployed and/or allocated as common controls, at the information system level, or at the operating system or component level (e.g., on workstations, servers, notebook computers, network components, or mobile devices). Tools can be used, for example, to track version numbers on operating system applications, types of software installed, and current patch levels.

Some of the recommendations for Configuration Management Tools (SCM Tools) are:

  1.  CFEngine Configuration Tool.
  2. Puppet Configuration Tool.
  3. CHEF Configuration Tool.
  4. Ansible Configuration Tool.
  5. SALTSTACK Configuration Tool.
  6. JUJU Configuration Tool.
  7. Microsoft Security Compliance Manager (SCM)
  •

Storage of sensitive data at rest must be encrypted at all times. Ensure that all sensitive data in databases and file stores are encrypted. Any data repositories that houses sensitive data should be encrypted by default. In addition, strong cryptography and security protocols (e.g. TLS, IPSEC, SSH, etc.) must be used to safeguard Confidential or Sensitive Information during transmission over open public networks. Cloud Key Management Service allows you to create, import, and manage cryptographic keys and perform cryptographic operations in a single centralized cloud service. In cases, where you use cloud provider key management services, ensure that access to production keys must be restricted to authorized individuals based on job needs. Maintain a list of authorized users who have access to encrypted key vaults.

A Key Management System can be implemented and used. Note: This could be an optional control depending on your organization and the product/service you provide. It is usually required for any cloud-based service.

  • Storage of customer/ sensitive data at rest must be encrypted at all times. Ensure that all customer/ sensitive data in databases and file stores are encrypted. Any data repositories that house sensitive data should be encrypted by default.
  • The encryption of data at rest should be through strong encryption methods such as AES or RSA. Encrypted data must remain encrypted when access controls such as usernames and passwords fail. Increasing encryption on multiple levels is recommended. Confidential or Sensitive Information at rest on computer systems owned or operated by Organization can be protected by one or more of the following mechanisms:
    • Disk/File System Encryption
    • Strong cryptography on authentication credentials (i.e. passwords/phrases) can be made unreadable during transmission and storage on all information systems.
    • Password protection to be used in combination with all controls, including encryption
    • File systems, disks, and tape drives in servers and Storage Area Network (SAN) environments are encrypted using industry-standard encryption technology.
    • Computer hard drives and other storage media that have been encrypted can be sanitized to prevent unauthorized exposure upon return for redistribution or disposal.

Ensure that all application communications containing sensitive data are encrypted in transit both internally and in any integrations with third parties. Strong cryptography and security protocols (e.g. TLS 1.2 etc.) must be used to safeguard Confidential or Sensitive Information during transmission over open public networks.

The organization needs to specify the minimum TLS encryption used for user authentication, customer logins and throughout the data transmission session. Transaction processing performed on web-based applications can be secured through the use of the Secure Socket Layer (SSL) encryption protocol over HTTPS connections. This includes the use of the website file upload page. Traffic directed to HTTP connections should be redirected to HTTPS connections.

All non-console administrative access such as browser/web-based management tools is encrypted using TLS based browser technologies using the most current security algorithm.

Establish a process for collecting system logs that are important for the organization in a centralized and aggregate matter. Define what logs are key for maintaining the integrity and availability of your systems and decide what logs will be analyzed and which ones will be collected for investigation purposes. Consider the size of your team, available automated tools and the complexity and criticality of your environment when formalizing the logging process.
- Determine what could constitute a loggable event,
- identify the activities that need to be logged (from system logs, access control logs, incident log storage/retention, malware detection events etc.).

Consider deploying a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) or log analytic tool for log correlation and analysis. When establishing your logging collection process, consider log integrity and security by limiting access to modify logging configuration and logging modification and backing them up if necessary, as well as defining retention expectations.

The organization should develop and implement a patch management process requiring to patch all network devices and systems on a periodic basis based on the recommendations provided by the vendor. Most vendors such as Microsoft provide an option for automated patching to ensure the systems are always staying up to date on the current patch issued by the vendor. However, there are a number of third-party tools available to assist in the patching process.

The organization should avoid patching directly in the production environment. The leading practice is to patch the system in a test environment to ensure the patch does not result in any unexpected issues prior to applying in the production environment.

The link below provides information on shared responsibility between customers and cloud service providers
  • AWS: https://aws.amazon.com/compliance/shared-responsibility-model/
  • Azure - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/security/fundamentals/shared-responsibility

Any patch(es) issued by the vendor addressing a critical vulnerability must be implemented immediately upon receipt following the organization's patch management process. 

The Secure Configuration Standard document under Resources > Guidance/Template section can be referred for this process.

Penetration testing demonstrates how vulnerabilities discovered during a vulnerability assessment can be exploited. It essentially shows the impact and consequences of a compromise due to the vulnerabilities. An example, if a system is not patched, penetration testers could well demonstrate what bad actors can do with an unpatched system, such as breaking in, gaining access to critical systems, elevating access, and then wreaking havoc by deleting or copying sensitive data. Penetration testing should be carried out at least once a year.

As a result, an organization should schedule periodic reviews of information systems to evaluate compliance with the organization's security policies and standards. Organizations need to conduct regular testing of their systems for the following key reasons:

  • Determine the weakness in the infrastructure (hardware), application (software) and people in order to develop controls
  • Ensure controls have been implemented and are effective
  • Test applications that are often the avenues of attack
  • Discover new bugs in existing software (patches and updates can fix existing vulnerabilities, but they can also introduce new vulnerabilities).

Penetration testing should be considered after the deployment of new infrastructure and applications as well as after major changes to infrastructure and applications (e.g. changes to firewall rules, updating of firmware, patches and upgrades to software).

Penetration testing must be carried out by competent, authorized persons or under the supervision of such persons.

  • Organizations should enable logging and monitoring of activities performed by administrators using their privileged access at the application and infrastructure level. Typically, activities such as login attempts, addition and or deletion of data, changes to functions, security configurations, permissions and roles, and any other activities performed using privileged accounts should be monitored and logged for investigation purposes.
  • Organizations should consider implementing automated alerts and monitoring tools configured to notify IT management when certain sensitive activities are performed by the administrators. The process should be in place requiring timely review of these notifications and follow-up/investigation in accordance with the organization's incident management process to identify, track and resolve issues within the timeframe defined within the incident management process.

For Serverless Functions (if applicable):

In serverless architecture, logs must be located on a central server so that their data can be preserved and analyzed after the function and container turn off. Thus, serverless logs must be collected and streamed to the analysis tool as part of the function execution so that data is not lost when the container is switched off.

In addition to standard administrative activities, log events such as changes to functions, security configurations, permissions and roles for Serverless Function.

Cloud providers often have built-in monitoring for application and function resources for logging and analysis, such as:

  • AWS X-Ray, ELK stack, and CloudWatch Logs are the most common method used for log analysis with AWS Lambda
  • Azure Security Centre and Cloudyn for Microsoft Azure
  • Stackdriver logging tool for GCP

Organizations should use the continuous health check automated alert systems offered by their serverless cloud provider to collect real-time logs from the different serverless functions. IT management should be provisioned to receive real-time alerts generated by the automated log system. Any issues discovered should be addressed in a reasonable timeframe in line with the incident management process.

Additionally, Serverless functions that call in external code and third-party libraries are monitored for attempts at injection and malicious activity.

The most secure serverless function can become vulnerable when importing code from a vulnerable third-party dependency. In order to deal with injection and malicious activity in third party components, a well-defined process that includes (but not limited to) to below should be established:

  • Maintaining an inventory of software packages and other dependencies and versions of them.
  • Vulnerability scanning should be performed as part of the ongoing continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) process.
  • Removal of unwanted dependencies, especially if your serverless functions no longer require such dependencies. - Using third-party packages only from secure services and ensuring the products have not been compromised.

When stateless authentication tokens are used for the implementation of shared libraries linked to a microservice, the following security measures must be observed:

  • Token expiry times should be as brief as possible.
  • The secret key of the token must not be part of the library code.

  • A firewall is a protective measure that safeguards an individual's or company's computer network. It provides two basic security functions including packet filtering, which inspects traffic at the packet level, and acting as an application proxy, providing security measures at the application level. Firewall configurations filter internet traffic based on content and destination site address, thus firewalls need to be configured to ensure that it limits unnecessary ports, protocols and services.
  • The minimum configuration includes:
    • Performing stateful packet inspection
    • Network Address Translation (NAT) services are enabled on all network firewalls to hide internal servers
    • Firewall ports are configured to allow only specific types of traffic between certain destinations. All unused ports on the firewall are blocked.
    • Deny all traffic that is not specifically authorized in the ruleset
  • IT management should ensure that a periodic firewall rules review (at least annually) is performed by organizations and documented in the form of service desk tickets or emails to demonstrate compliance.

For continuous availability of services, it is important for the IT team to perform continuous monitoring of system capacity and performance using tools and techniques, whether developed in-house or third-party solution. The tools should be configured to notify the appropriate individual(s) within the organization of the identified and detected anomalies impacting the organization's commitment to the availability and performance of the system.

The individuals notified should then carry out an investigation in accordance with the organization's incident management process.

Vulnerability scans look for vulnerabilities in your systems and applications and report any potential vulnerabilities. They should be performed on a regular basis (quarterly, bi-annually) or whenever there is a significant change in the infrastructure or application.

Vulnerability scans can be external or internal 

  • An internal vulnerability scan is carried out from inside an organization's perimeter defences. Its purpose is to detect vulnerabilities that could be exploited by hackers who successfully penetrate the perimeter defences or equally by "insider threats" such as contractors or disgruntled employees.
  • An external vulnerability scan is carried out from outside an organization's network. Its principal purpose is to detect vulnerabilities in the perimeter defences such as open ports in the network firewall or specialized web application firewall.

Basic: Using open-source application and network scanning tools to scan for vulnerabilities, open ports, devices and networks using scanning tools and services.
Advanced: Utilize third-party scanning services to automatically scan organization networks and applications.

An effective vulnerability management process involves:
- Identification of vulnerabilities
- Evaluation of the risk posed by any vulnerabilities identified
- Treatment of any identified vulnerabilities
- Reporting on vulnerabilities and how they have been handled

  • Basic: Create and use code review checklists to manually check for common security and quality issues.
  • Advanced: Create processes with code pull requests to formally review and approve developer code prior to merging into the codebase.

Other recommended open-source solutions for code review are Puma Scan or Sonar Cloud. Typical issues with the free/open-source tools are that they don't have robust reporting capabilities and they have limited support and liability. That said, they will still meet the requirements of code review. The auditor doesn't usually look at the tool used, they look at the vulnerability report and your response to those vulnerabilities. If the application you choose doesn't generate a vulnerability report, then you would need to integrate the tool with a reporting tool that you have.

For Serverless Function (if applicable):

Code scanning is performed to identify and patch vulnerabilities in the serverless functions. Identified vulnerabilities are remediated in accordance with the organization's policy and process.

Serverless computing is an execution model in which a cloud provider dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources and schedules the execution of functions provided by users. This new model raises new security concerns, while some familiar old concerns still apply. The vulnerabilities in your code and associated dependencies are the sources attackers use to compromise an application.

Periodically scan your serverless functions. If possible, use automated source code scanning of serverless functions. Vulnerability scanning should be performed as part of the ongoing continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI / CD) process. Consider:

  • Removal of unwanted dependencies, especially if your serverless functions no longer require such dependencies.
  • Using third-party packages only from secure services and ensuring the products have not been compromised.
  • Updating obsolete versions of packages to the new versions and applying all critical software patches.

Serverless computing is an execution model in which a cloud provider dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources and schedules the execution of functions provided by users. This new model raises new security concerns, while some familiar old concerns still apply. The vulnerabilities in your code and associated dependencies are the sources attackers use to compromise an application.

Periodically scan your serverless functions. If possible, use automated source code scanning of serverless functions. Vulnerability scanning should be performed as part of the ongoing continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI / CD) process. Consider:
- Removal of unwanted dependencies, especially if your serverless functions no longer require such dependencies.
- Using third-party packages only from secure services and ensuring the products have not been compromised.
- Updating obsolete versions of packages to the new versions and applying all critical software patches.

All third-party contractors or vendors engaged with the organization are required to sign a contractual agreement and a code of conduct to demonstrate commitments to the organization's ethical values as well as security and confidentiality commitments prior to engaging with the organization. The organization should establish contractor/vendor agreements to ensure that there is no misunderstanding between both parties regarding their obligations to fulfill relevant requirements with respect to security, confidentiality and code of conduct. Such agreements should include (as applicable):

  • Description of the information to be provided or accessed
  • Legal and regulatory requirements, including data protection, intellectual property rights and copyright
  • The obligation of each contractual party to implement an agreed set of security controls
  • Rules of acceptable use of information
  • Information security policies relevant to the specific contract
  • Incident management requirements and procedures
  • Training and awareness requirements for specific procedures and information security
  • Contractor's/vendor's obligations to comply with the organization’s security requirements.

Organizations must evaluate third-party vendors at least annually in accordance with their defined vendor management process.

The evaluation is based on the impact of the vendor's services on the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the organization's data and services. Such instances include but are not limited to

  • The organization's services and/or system(s) depend on a third-party vendor like a cloud service provider or data center provider. This is because its services are hosted on a vendor's platform or infrastructure. (Azure, AWS, GCP etc.)
  • The organization stores sensitive data using the vendor's storage services (cloud storage services - OneDrive, Citrix, drive, etc.)
  • The vendor's application is used to transmit sensitive information.
  • The vendor's application is used to manage and communicate with customers, as well as for incident management (email services, customer support and incident management tools)

Relevant supporting documentation and information (e.g. industry-standard assurance/attestation reports (SOC 1/SOC 2), inquiries, completed questionnaires) are obtained and assessed in order to:

  1. Re-evaluate the services provided and identify any new risks arising from the relationship,
  2. Evaluating the period of compliance,
  3. Evaluate the appropriateness and effectiveness of relevant vendor controls and the impact of control exceptions, if any identified in compliance reports, and
  4. Validate the Company is adhering to relevant complementary user-entity control considerations, if any.

Refer to the template "Vendor Assessment - Review of Compliance Report" to aid with evidence collection.

Compliance reports for a few vendors

  • AWS - https://aws.amazon.com/artifact/
  • GCP - https://cloud.google.com/security/compliance/compliance-reports-manager
  • Azure - https://servicetrust.microsoft.com/Documents/ComplianceReports

  • Organizations should implement a formal vendor management process to evaluate the potential vendors ("suppliers or third parties") during onboarding as well as on a periodic basis (e.g. annually) to evaluate their compliance to agreed responsibilities thereafter.
  • A key component of effective vendor risk management is oversight and monitoring. The extent of oversight will depend on the types of vendor risk they present and the scope of the relationship, but the organization must have qualified staff allocated to monitoring vendor relationships.
  • The monitoring of vendor performance can be done through obtaining and reviewing their third-party audit reports on internal controls, quality of their services, compliance with contractual terms, meeting Service level agreements (SLAs), etc. Link to AWS compliance reports https://aws.amazon.com/artifact/.
  • Refer to the sample template using this link Vendor Assessment - Review of Compliance to evaluate your vendors' performance on security compliance by verifying their SOC reports annually.

Organizations need to have processes in place to identify when and how vendors/ third parties should be terminated and to ensure completion of the procedures associated with the proper termination of the relationship by implementing formal procedures for terminating vendor and business partner relationships. Implemented formal Vendor management process

The Vendor management process should include processes to be followed by an organization in all phases of vendor lifecycle, starting from planning, due diligence, contracting, management up to terminations. As part of terminations, review the Vendor Contract Termination Provisions to ensure contractual obligations are adhered to.

Install organization-approved anti-virus (AV) and or anti-spam software. Ensure organization workstations security settings and firewall are enabled.

  • Windows workstations: ensure that Windows Defender runs weekly scheduled scans and Real-time Protection switched on.
  • Mac and Linux workstations: ensure antivirus is installed, running and AV definition is up to date.

For workstations not centrally managed, enable the firewall using the guide below

  • Mac Firewall
  • Windows

Enable disk encryption:
For Windows workstations, enable BitLocker.
For Mac workstations, enable FileVault.
For Linux, enable dm-crypt.

Other recommendations include:
- Sophos SafeGuard Encryption
- Symantec Endpoint Encryption
- McAfee Complete Data Protection Advanced

Recommend: Set up a device password/passcode/fingerprint scanner/ facial recognition and configure an auto-locking screensaver after 5 minutes at most. This ensures that should a laptop/computer be stolen or lost, the data is still secured.

Patch management is the process of distributing and applying updates to the software. These patches are often necessary to correct errors (also referred to as “vulnerabilities” or “bugs”) in the software. It is important to establish a formal patch management process with a detailed organizational process that is both cost-effective and security-focused. Accordingly, regularly apply patches to all systems using a patch management solution like Windows Update or other patch management solutions. Key steps to the patch management process include:

- Develop an up-to-date inventory of all your production systems
- Devise a plan for standardizing systems and operating systems to the same version type
- Make a list of all security controls that are in place within your organization
- Compare reported vulnerabilities against your inventory
- Classify the risk and determine assets you consider to be critical to your organization and prioritize
- Test the patches
- Apply the patches
- Post review

Establish processes to control the unique identities of users and services. The process for managing user IDs should include using unique user IDs to enable users to be linked to and held responsible for their actions; the use of shared IDs should only be permitted where they are necessary for business or operational reasons and should be approved and documented.

Enforce the use of individual user IDs and strong passwords to maintain accountability.

Below is an example of different password parameters to achieve strong quality passwords:

  • Minimum password length: 8 characters or more characters (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Password complexity: Enabled
  • Password History - 24 Passwords (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Maximum Password Age - 90 days (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Lockout attempts: 5-10 attempts (determined by the organization's policy)
  • Multi-factor Authentication

For Serverless Functions (if applicable):

The authentication resources provided by the serverless environment can also be used. For example, AWS Cognito or Single Sign-On AWS API Gateway authorization facilities (link) Azure App Service Authentication / Authorization Google Firebase Authentication IBM BlueMix AppID or SSO.

MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication) adds extra security because it requires users to provide unique authentication in addition to their regular sign-in credentials. There are various methods to setup authentication for serverless functions, such as:

  • OAuth Authentication - Running your application serverless with the latest and more secure mode of authentication
  • API Key Authentication - The simplest and the fastest way to enable authentication.

Enforce documented password parameters for access to applications through automated configurations such as minimum password length, complexity, password history, maximum age, account lockout interval, and threshold.
The use of unique accounts must be enforced i.e. dedicated account for each user. Use of generic accounts (if needed for business purpose), must be logged and monitored.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is an effective way to provide enhanced security that verifies a user's identity by requiring multiple credentials. If a system/service has a multi-factor authentication (MFA) functionality, turn it on.

Examples of Multi-Factor Authentication include using a combination of these elements to authenticate:

    • Codes generated by smartphone apps
    • Badges, USB devices, or other physical devices
    • Soft tokens, certificates
    • Fingerprints
    • Codes sent to an email address
    • Facial recognition
    • Retina or iris scanning
    • Behavioural analysis
    • Answers to personal security questions

In addition to a password, consider multi-factor authentication for enhanced security with these factors
- Things you know (knowledge), such as a password or PIN
- Things you have (possession), such as a badge or smartphone
- Things you are (inheritance), indicated through biometrics, like fingerprints or voice recognition

It is essential that all critical applications should have Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) allowed.

A standardized procedure for granting and revoking access should be established. Access to systems and supporting infrastructure should be granted to users based on the standardized process and after approval from designated personnel on the principle of least privilege required to perform job functions. Documented approval in the form of email, ticket, or checklist should be retained as audit evidence. 

Basic: Create and maintain a spreadsheet that tracks all employees and which corporate accounts/systems and supporting infrastructure that they have been provided access to and who authorized their specified access. Track when they have been given access and when access has been removed depending upon whether their roles have changed or if they have left the organization. Please ensure the access to spreadsheets is restricted to authorized personnel only and tracks version control.

Advanced: Implement an HR and People Management onboarding system that is integrated with your Identity & Access Management (IAM) system. Activate and Suspend (do not delete) user accounts to preserve audit trails.

For Serverless Functions (If applicable):

The organization should have a procedure to provide access to accounts that call out services and enforce authentication with the use of serverless authentication methods. There are various methods to setup authentication for serverless functions, such as:

  • OAuth Authentication - Running your application serverless with the latest and more secure mode of authentication
  • API Key Authentication - The simplest and the fastest way to enable authentication.

Access to serverless functions should be on the principle of least privilege, meaning you can only access exactly what you need the following authorization. In addition, most serverless functions have different needs; creating a single role for all the functions in the application can open up security holes. The risk can be mitigated by creating a different role for every function and restricting each function to its intended purpose.

Establish and follow a termination checklist to ensure that the termination process is consistently executed and access is revoked for terminated employees in a timely manner. For the list, consider:

  • The type of access to be revoked (ex. Physical access to the building or administrator access to a software tool).
  • Physical assets that need to be returned (ex. ID cards or laptops).
  • Network and system access - ensure access is terminated on the same day. Also, to any applications or system components that the terminated user had access to.
  • Passwords for shared accounts - ensure passwords to such accounts are either changed or disabled (as required). This also includes email and remote access.

Upon notification, system administrators will disable/delete the employees' user accounts in applicable systems, including supporting systems and sensitive utilities (application, database, and support services servers; databases; cloud storage).

Basic: Use an onboarding/offboarding document and process where HR personnel informs system administrators or asset owners for timely revocation of access.
Advanced: Implement a central access control system to manage access depending on their employment status and job changes.

  • Create a dedicated account for personnel requiring privileged access commensurate with their job responsibilities.
  • These accounts should not be used for browsing the web, checking email, and doing day-to-day tasks.
  • Activities performed using these accounts should be logged and monitored. The organization should try to minimize the use of generic administrator accounts. In the event that it is not possible, only very few people should have access to it, and the access should be provided on a need-to-have basis.

In order to assess whether the accounts (user and non-users) with administrative access are restricted to authorized personnel, management can rely on the evidence of access reviews performed for such accounts. Additionally, evidence of the user's job titles/designations can be provided to inspect the appropriateness.

In order to detect any unauthorized access to organizational systems, a periodic review (preferably quarterly) of user access rights along with roles associated with it needs to be performed. The reviews must be performed by designated management personnel or asset owner and are required to be documented for audit purposes. Things to consider while performing access reviews:
- Perform review on all accounts (user as well as non-user accounts) and roles associated with it
- Users with access should not perform a review of their own accounts. For exceptions, a secondary review needs to be performed by other management personnel
- Document the review and corrective actions resulting from it. Corrective actions must be implemented at the earliest following review.
- Review, as well as the implementation of corrective actions, needs to be performed in a timely manner.

Based on review if there is an identified need for an access change or corrective action, then this must be documented and reported for change to be modified as appropriate. Documentation of reviews includes - tickets, emails, listings used to perform the review, results of review captured through emails or tickets, etc.

Customer data are logically separated by an organization ID (org_id) column in the DB and enforced using logic rules. It can also be segregated by maintaining separate S3 buckets per customer and a shared database by regions (store US data separate from EU).

Organizationally-owned or managed (physical and virtual) applications, and infrastructure system and network components, shall be designed, developed, deployed, and configured such that provider and customer (tenant) user access is appropriately segmented from other tenant users, based on the following considerations:
Established policies and procedures
Isolation of business critical assets and/or sensitive user data, and sessions that mandate stronger internal controls and high levels of assurance
Compliance with legal, statutory, and regulatory compliance obligations

Segregation of Duties (SOD) is a basic building block of sustainable risk management and internal controls for a business. The basic concept underlying segregation of duties is that no employee or group should be in a position both to perpetrate and to conceal errors or fraud in the normal course of their duties. Thus, SOD is accomplished by having different duties performed by different individuals, such as developers should not have access to implement or promote changes into production. Only designated individuals from IT can promote changes to production following the organization's change management process.

If the organization is unable to implement SOD control as recommended due to the size of the team or any other restrictions, they should consider compensating controls and/or detective controls to mitigate the risk posed by excessive access (inappropriate SOD). Some examples of additional controls that can be considered include but not limited to:

  • Provide temporary access to production (emergency access or also known as firefighter access). Such access can be provided for an approved window of time and later revoked. Since the access is provided to a handful of people, it makes it easier to review the activity logs.
  • Organizations can perform code reviews or review change logs in production. 
  • Alert notification can be configured on the production server to send notification emails or alerts whenever a change is directly migrated to the production server. Alerts should be assigned and reviewed by the authorized personnel.

  • We recommend using OneTrust platform to manage your organization's information security policies and procedures.
  • Review, customize and publish the pre-populated policies in your infosec program to align them with your organization processes.
  • Ensure that policies are reviewed and approved by management at least annually and accessible to all the employees of the organization through the Policy module via the "InfoSec Program" menu on the left navigation bar of the platform.
  • The policy should include the organization's mission and objectives.
